EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Vintage Petroleum Inc. (Vintage) is the owner of the Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant (SCVGP).  Vintage adheres to written operating procedures to protect its employees, environment, property, and the general public from any off-site impacts that could occur as a result of operations at the plant.  Vintage operates its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations, which serves to reinforce its long-standing commitment to worker and public safety at their facilities.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention such as personnel training, building safety into the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility.  The Vintage philosophy is to implement engineering and administrative controls to eliminate preventable releases of regulated substances, as well as non-regulated substances.

The Vintage SCVGP Emergency Response Plan incorporates coordination with local emergency response agencies as well as the use of employees trained to recognize and respond to the hazards of a chemical release and the use of response procedures to mitigate the release of such chemicals to the environment.  The highest priority in an emergency response is for the safety of responding emergency personnel as well as affected and non-affected personnel.  Response procedures are implemented according to what is appropriate based on a hazard assessments performed at the scene of the incident.  Vintage will always attempt to have a Joint Incident Command structure in place to assist emergency response personnel in the immediate control of any release.  Priorities for response are based on life, environment and property, in that order.

Management supports the safety of the plant by having management representation (Pipeline Foreman) on site at the plant and by providing annual training for its e

mployees in HAZWOPER 29 CFR 1910.120, Emergency Action Plans 29 CFR 1910.38, (including tabletop drills that sometimes include local emergency response agencies depending on their availability), Fire Prevention Plans 29 CFR 1910.39 and training requirements of 20 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management.  

1.2 Facility Description
The Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant is located in Ventura County, approximately 25 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 6 miles south of Piru, California.  Torrey Canyon Road dead-ends into Guiberson Road at the entrance to the facility.  The facility is relatively remote and bounded by undeveloped private property on the south and southeast and citrus groves on the northeast.  A dry creek wash (Torrey Canyon Wash) is located along the northeast boundary of the facility.

1.3 Regulated Substances
Regulated flammable mixtures containing methane, ethane, propane, butane, pentane and iso-pentane are present at the facility.  No regulated toxic substances are present at the facility in excess of the threshold quantities establish by this regulation. 1.4 Summary of Accidental Release Prevention Program
The Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant is subject to RMP requirements as well as OSHA?s 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management of highly hazardous chemicals (PSM).  The Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant, by complying with the PSM and RMP standards, has implemented all of the requirements of the RMP Program 3 prevention program.

Compliance with PSM?s comprehensive program ensures the operating integrity of the plant processes that handle flammable materials.  The objective of the company?s PSM program is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals.  To control these types of hazards, Vintage has proactively identified, evaluated and developed operating and maintenance procedures to prevent, or at least mitigate, the release of chemical

s due to failures in the process or equipment.  Vintage relies on its workforce expertise, experience, judgment and training to properly implement and maintain the PSM program.  An effective PSM program requires a systematic approach to evaluating the entire chemical process.  The various lines of defense that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals have been evaluated and tested to assure their effectiveness at each level.  The elements of the company?s PSM are discussed further, below.

Process Safety Information - This includes complete and accurate written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment of the natural gas processing system in the plant.  The PSI manual is readily available to employees. 

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA ) ? An initial PHA was performed at the plant to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of flammable materials.  The PHA is revalidated every 3 years and assists the company and its employees in making decisions for improving safety and reducing the consequences of unwanted or unplanned releases of flammable materials.  As part of the company?s PSM compliance of various elements a cross functional team performs the PHA.  

Operating Procedures - As part of the PSM program, all operating procedures for the natural gas processing system are documented and accessible to employees whose work involves this system.  Each operator has his/her own set of operating procedures for easy access and notations.  As needed, changes or updates to the natural gas processing system operating procedures are incorporated under the company?s management of change program and operators are trained annually on the operating procedures.

Employee Training - Personnel performing operations or maintenance on the natural gas process system must be qualified to perform their assi

gned tasks.  The company has an established training program that ensures the training and competency of employees whose jobs require them to perform work on the natural gas processing system.  Training includes operating procedures, maintenance procedures, HAZWOPER, Emergency Response, Fire Prevention Plan, HazComm, Lock out/Tagout, and other training as applicable and required by Federatl and State OSHA.

Mechanical Integrity - Under the PSM program, equipment used to process, store, or handle flammable materials has to be designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the release of such chemicals.  As required, elements of the mechanical integrity program include identifying and categorizing equipment and instrumentation, inspections and tests and their frequency; maintenance procedures; training of maintenance personnel; criteria for acceptable test results; and documentation of manufacturer recommendations for equipment and instrumentation.  

Management of Change - Changes to a process must be evaluated thoroughly to fully assess their impact on employee safety and health and to determine needed changes to the process.  The company has established and implemented a management of change program for any changes that are not ?replacements in kind?.  These changes include process chemicals, technology equipment and operating and maintenance procedures, and changes to facilities that affect the natural gas processing system.  A log is kept to document the MOC and safety meetings are held to inform all employees of the change. 

Pre-Startup Safety Review - Vintage performs a pre-startup safety review for new facilities and for modified facilities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.  A PSSR is performed prior to start up of new processes which require a hazardous material above the regulatory threshold and anytime the facility undergoes modifications.  For existing processes that have been

shutdown for turnaround or modification, company policy ensures that any changes other than ?replacement of kind? made to the process during shutdown go through the management of change process and pre-start-up safety review.

Compliance Audits - Vintage performs an audit of their PSM program every three years as required by the PSM standard.  The audit is used to gather facts and information to verify compliance with the PSM standards.  The audit includes an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the PSM program and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that the PSM program elements are effectively implemented.  The audit is documented and the last two audits maintained in the files.

Incident Investigation ? A crucial part of Vintage?s PSM program is a thorough investigation of all incidents that caused, or could have potentially caused a release of hazardous chemicals.  The investigation seeks to identify the chain of events and root causes so that corrective measures can be developed and implemented to prevent reoccurrence.  Vintage uses a team of employees to conduct the investigation and documents the findings and recommendations.  These are shared with employees in safety meetings to educate them in how to avoid another incident in the future.  

Employee Participation Plan ? Vintage employees participate in every element of PSM.  Employees are included in PHA revalidation teams; incident investigation teams; they assist in writing operating and maintenance procedures, conducting compliance audits, attending training, screening contractors and reporting on contractor performance, maintaining both the PSI and Mechanical Integrity information, and initiating MOC and PSSRs are needed.  

Company Supervisors attend and participate in safety meetings conducted by Contract Supervisors as needed to review Company environmental and safety policies prior to contract personnel performing major work or operations presentin

g special environmental or safety concerns.

Contractors - Third party contractors conduct their operations in the safe and environmentally sound manner.  Contractor safety and environmental provisions must meet or exceed Company requirements and satisfy applicable Federal, state and local laws and regulations.  The Company audits its contractors in several areas, including job safety performance, qualifications, and training programs to name a few areas of the audit.

1.5 Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
In addition to implementation of the PSM elements, Vintage has implemented specific safety features for the prevention, detection and control of releases or regulated (and other) substances at the Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant.  The following is some of the control and detection equipment located in and around the facility to minimize the risk of an accident involving hazardous materials at Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant:
?    Relief and/or safety valves
?    High temperature alarms and/or shutdowns
?    Flame detectors
?    Combustible gas detectors
?    Smoke detectors
?    Fire Protection System
?    Emergency Shutdown Systems (ESD)
?    Leak Detection System
1.6 Five-Year Accident History
The Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant has had no incidents with off-site impacts involving a regulated substance as defined in the regulation in the past five years.

1.7 Emergency Response Program Summary
Vintage has written emergency response procedures to address hazards that may be encountered during response or follow-up of an emergency at the Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant.  These emergency response procedures address the following issues: 1) releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of fires or explosions; 2) proper emergency rescue, first aid and medical treatment for exposure; 3) notification of local emergency response agencies; 4) evacuation plans for the Santa Clara Gas Plant and methods of accounting for facility personnel after an evacuation; and 5) post-incident cleanup/decon

tamination requirements.  In addition, the Santa Clara Valley Gas Plant follows procedures that address the maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment and alarms on a routine basis.

Written emergency response procedures are in compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 Emergency Action Plans and the emergency response element of PSM.  Training on the emergency response plan enhances the preparedness of employees to recognize and respond to any release of hazardous chemicals.  The emergency response procedures provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies including prevention, preparedness, hazard assessment, response, rescue, decontamination and follow-up procedures.

In addition to the above, Vintage also complies with 29 CFR 1910.39, Fire Prevention Plan. The purpose of the fire prevention plan is to inform employees of the:  1.) major fire hazards in the process area; 2.) proper handling and storage procedures for hazardous materials; 3.) potential ignition sources and their control; and 4.) type of fire protection equipment necessary to control each major hazard within the process area and surrounding areas of the plant.  The fire prevention plan includes procedures to control accumulations of flammable materials and also procedures for regular maintenance of safeguards installed on heat-producing equipment to prevent the accidental ignition of flammable materials in the process.  

1.9 Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
Currently, there are no changes or additions planned for improved safety.  Since the last RMP submittal, a flare system was installed for complete combustion of most fugitive gas releases from the plant due to compressor shut downs and vapor vented from vessels during process upsets.
